story.text:
As a mother of three, Kat Nouri was dismayed at the amount of 
single-use plastic she was using to pack her kids' school lunches. She 
had already launched a successful brand called Modern Twist, which sold 
placemats and baby bibs made of silicone. So Kat wondered: why
 not use silicone to make durable food storage bags, which—instead of 
being used once, could be used thousands of times? In 2016 she launched 
Stasher, and was soon persuading retailers that an $11 reusable bag was 
better for the planet—and ultimately, more cost-effective for the 
big-box shopper. Kat successfully sold the brand to S.C. Johnson just a few years after launch. [https://www.npr.org/2021/11/19/1057386872/stasher-and-modern-twist-kat-nouri npr]

https://www.npr.org/player/embed/1057386872/1057392733
HEIGHT 180
Stasher & Modern Twist: Kat Nouri. How I Built This.
[https://www.npr.org/2021/11/19/1057386872/stasher-and-modern-twist-kat-nouri npr]
1h02m30s Tell me why? To sell to S.C. Johnson?
I wanted Stasher to be in the hands of everyone if it was going to make real change. It's all about distribution. Who has distribution?
They have companies that are changing the footprint of the way multinationals do business and the way things are produced.
For the record. I didn't get acquired. I brought the acquirers to the table. I sought anybody that would have an arm for massive distribution to get Stasher out and I weeded them out.

better for the planet—and ultimately, more cost-effective for the 
big-box shopper. Kat successfully sold the brand to S.C. Johnson just a few years after launch. [https://www.npr.org/2021/11/19/1057386872/stasher-and-modern-twist-kat-nouri npr]
